definitions: happening or done before the usual or proper time; too early
not fully developed or mature; lacking necessary development or preparation
examples: The premature announcement caused confusion among the investors
Her premature departure from the meeting surprised everyone
The premature baby required special medical care
His premature conclusions proved to be completely wrong

definitions: thought out or planned beforehand, especially describing criminal intent or deliberate action
examples: The prosecutor argued it was a premeditated murder
Their premeditated response showed careful planning

definitions: most important, leading, or chief in rank, quality, or significance
first in time or occurring before anything else in order
examples: She works at the premier law firm in the city
The premier university attracts students from around the world
The premier performance of the symphony was exceptional
This was the premier showing of the documentary

definitions: relating to or being the first public performance or showing of something
examples: The premiere episode drew millions of viewers
They attended the premiere screening at the festival

definitions: of exceptional quality or greater value than standard options
involving or requiring payment of a higher price than usual
examples: They only serve premium coffee at this cafe
The hotel offers premium amenities to all guests
Premium gasoline costs more but improves performance
You'll pay premium prices during peak season

definitions: occurring or existing before birth, relating to pregnancy and fetal development
examples: Regular prenatal care is essential for healthy pregnancies
The doctor prescribed prenatal vitamins for the mother

definitions: completely engrossed in thought; having one's attention fully engaged by something
examples: She seemed preoccupied during the entire meeting
He was too preoccupied with work to notice

definitions: paid for before receiving or using a service or product
examples: She bought a prepaid phone card for emergencies
The prepaid shipping label was included in the package

definitions: serving as preparation or introduction; done to get ready for something
examples: The preparatory work took several months to complete
Students attend preparatory classes before the main course

definitions: made ready beforehand for a specific purpose or event
ready and willing to do something; having necessary skills or resources
examples: The prepared statement was read to the press
She brought prepared meals for the week
He wasn't prepared for such difficult questions
The team is prepared to face any challenge

definitions: relating to or formed with a preposition in grammar
examples: The prepositional phrase modifies the noun
Students struggled with prepositional usage in sentences

definitions: contrary to reason or common sense; utterly absurd or ridiculous
examples: His preposterous claim was immediately dismissed
The preposterous price made everyone laugh

definitions: recorded in advance rather than broadcast or played live
examples: The interview was prerecorded last week
They played a prerecorded message for callers

definitions: required as a prior condition for something else to happen or exist
examples: Calculus is a prerequisite course for physics
Experience is prerequisite for this senior position

definitions: having or showing knowledge of events before they take place; prophetic
examples: Her prescient warnings about the market proved accurate
The author's prescient vision anticipated modern technology

definitions: established or laid down as a rule or directive by authority
ordered as a medicine or treatment by a medical professional
examples: Students must follow the prescribed curriculum
The prescribed format must be used for all reports
She takes prescribed medication for her condition
The doctor prescribed antibiotics for the infection

definitions: available only with a doctor's written instruction for medicine
examples: These are prescription drugs requiring doctor approval
She needs prescription glasses for driving

definitions: relating to the imposition or enforcement of rules or standards
stating how language should be used rather than describing actual usage
examples: The prescriptive approach dictates exact procedures
Their prescriptive guidelines left no room for creativity
Traditional prescriptive grammar forbids split infinitives
The prescriptive rules ignored common usage patterns

definitions: existing or occurring at this time; current
being in a particular place; not absent
given or presented as a gift
examples: The present situation requires immediate attention
Present technology makes this task much easier
All members were present at the meeting
The bacteria present in the sample were identified
This present edition includes new chapters
The present volume contains updated research

definitions: serving to preserve something, especially food from decay or spoilage
examples: The preservative coating protects the wood from moisture
Foods with preservative additives last longer

definitions: maintained in its original or existing state; kept intact
treated to prevent decomposition or deterioration
examples: The preserved medieval castle attracts many tourists
These preserved documents date back centuries
The preserved fruit can last for months
Scientists study preserved specimens in the lab

definitions: established or determined beforehand; configured before use
examples: The oven has several preset temperature settings
Use the preset options for quick configuration

definitions: of, relating to, or befitting a president or presidency
examples: The presidential election occurs every four years
She delivered a presidential address to the nation

definitions: flattened or shaped by pressure; compressed
experiencing stress or urgency; under pressure
examples: She wore a crisply pressed uniform
The pressed flowers were preserved in the book
We're pressed for time before the deadline
The pressed manager struggled to meet demands

definitions: requiring quick or immediate action or attention; urgent
examples: We have more pressing matters to discuss first
The pressing need for reform became evident

definitions: inspiring respect and admiration; having high status or reputation
examples: She graduated from a prestigious university
The prestigious award recognizes lifetime achievement

definitions: giving reasonable grounds for belief; likely to become or be
examples: The presumptive nominee began planning the campaign
This is presumptive evidence of their involvement

definitions: relating to or being a child between nine and twelve years old
examples: The preteen audience loved the new movie
She teaches preteen students at middle school

definitions: not genuine; imaginary or make-believe
examples: The children played with pretend money
She lives in a pretend world of fantasy

definitions: falsely appearing or claimed to be something; feigned
examples: His pretended ignorance didn't fool anyone
She showed pretended interest in the conversation

definitions: attempting to impress by affecting greater importance or merit than actually possessed
examples: His pretentious manner annoyed his colleagues
The restaurant's pretentious menu used unnecessary French terms

definitions: most frequent or common; predominant
existing at a particular time; current
examples: The prevailing opinion favors the new proposal
Prevailing winds come from the west
The prevailing conditions make travel dangerous
Under prevailing circumstances, we must postpone

definitions: widespread in a particular area or at a particular time; common
examples: This disease is prevalent in tropical regions
Such attitudes were prevalent during that era

definitions: capable of being prevented or avoided; not inevitable
examples: Many accidents are entirely preventable with proper care
This was a preventable tragedy that shouldn't have happened

definitions: designed to prevent disease, difficulty, or other unwanted occurrences
examples: Regular exercise is a preventative measure against heart disease
The company implemented preventative maintenance procedures

definitions: designed to prevent disease, difficulty, or other unwanted occurrences
examples: Preventive medicine focuses on staying healthy
They took preventive action against flooding

definitions: existing or occurring before in time or order; former
examples: Her previous experience prepared her well
The previous owner had renovated the house

definitions: existing or occurring before a war, especially World War II
examples: The prewar architecture was largely destroyed
Prewar society had different values and norms

definitions: so precious that its value cannot be determined; invaluable
extremely amusing or absurd
examples: The museum houses priceless artifacts from ancient civilizations
Her priceless contribution to science changed everything
His priceless expression when surprised was unforgettable
That priceless comment made everyone burst out laughing

definitions: covered with prickles or thorns; causing a stinging sensation
quick to take offense; bad-tempered or irritable
examples: The prickly cactus plant requires careful handling
She felt a prickly sensation on her skin
He becomes prickly when criticized about his work
Their prickly relationship made collaboration difficult

definitions: of, relating to, or befitting a priest or the priesthood
examples: He wore traditional priestly vestments for the ceremony
Her priestly duties included conducting services

definitions: stiffly formal and respectable; showing disapproval of anything improper
examples: Her prim manner made casual conversation difficult
The prim Victorian lady never showed emotion

definitions: relating to the fundamental or most important aspects
relating to an early stage of evolutionary development; primeval
examples: Fear is a primal human emotion
The primal urge to survive drives behavior
The primal forest remained untouched by civilization
They studied primal human societies

definitions: of chief importance; principal or main
earliest in time or order of development; not derived
examples: Safety is our primary concern in this project
The primary goal is to increase efficiency
Primary colors cannot be created by mixing
She teaches primary school children

definitions: of the best possible quality; excellent
most important or primary; chief
divisible only by itself and one
examples: This is prime real estate in the city center
The restaurant serves prime cuts of beef
Our prime objective is customer satisfaction
She was a prime candidate for the position
Seven is a prime number
The prime factorization helps solve the equation

definitions: prepared for a particular purpose or situation; made ready
examples: The team is primed for victory tonight
She was primed to take over the leadership role

definitions: of or resembling the earliest ages in history; ancient and primitive
examples: The primeval forest has existed for millennia
Primeval instincts emerged in dangerous situations

definitions: relating to an early stage of human development or evolution
very basic or unsophisticated in terms of comfort or technology
examples: Primitive humans used stone tools for hunting
They studied primitive art from ancient cultures
The cabin had primitive facilities with no electricity
Their primitive methods proved surprisingly effective

definitions: existing at or from the beginning of time; primeval
examples: Scientists study primordial matter from the universe's birth
The primordial soup theory explains life's origins

definitions: munificent or lavish in a way suggesting wealth or high rank
of, relating to, or befitting a prince
examples: He received a princely sum for his services
They lived in princely splendor
The princely estate covered thousands of acres
His princely bearing impressed the court
